headline.main: After Hitler, Bin Laden Isn't So Scary; In Response to Terror, A New Generation Gap

lead_paragraph: Jess Biblowitz remains calm in the face of menace, uneasy about the stock market and the possibility of a military draft but not given to apocalyptic visions. Roy Kean feels swells of patriotism that send him browsing the ''help wanted'' page on the C.I.A. Web site. David Diggs plans to leave New York City, join his girlfriend in the Middle West and find a secure job in what has become an insecure economy. Mr. Biblowitz is 81, a World War II veteran. He says that people his age have little to lose in the current crisis, not enough energy for panic and a high threshold for adversity. Mr. Kean, 53, avoided the Vietnam War with a favorable lottery number. He says that people in their 40's and 50's already had the scare of a lifetime during the Cuban missile crisis. Mr. Diggs is 28 and knows nothing of war but plenty about prosperity. He says that his age group is reeling, their blithe assumptions buried in the World Trade Center rubble.
abstract: Article discusses how those who lived through Hitler's Nazi regime and Vietnam War era view current terrorist situation and war in Afghanistan; photo (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES
